To illustrate the potential severity of the problem described above, and preview the contributions of this paper, consider the following simple example. Let c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1} and c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2} be two clients with distinct data distributions. A server aims to optimize the function Fâ€‹(ğ°)=p1â€‹F1â€‹(ğ°)+p2â€‹F2â€‹(ğ°)ğ¹ğ°subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ¹1ğ°subscriptğ‘2subscriptğ¹2ğ°F(\mathbf{w})=p_{1}F_{1}(\mathbf{w})+p_{2}F_{2}(\mathbf{w}) over â„psuperscriptâ„ğ‘\mathbb{R}^{p}, where F1subscriptğ¹1F_{1} and F2subscriptğ¹2F_{2} denote the loss functions at clients c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1} and c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2}, respectively, and for simplicity p1=p2=1/2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘212p_{1}=p_{2}=1/2. We shall consider a model for the clientsâ€™ intermittent availability characterized by the joint distributions given in TableÂ 1,
where Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i} is a binary random variable indicating whether client cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i} is available. In this model, clientsâ€™ availabilities in a given round are independent, with Pâ€‹(A1=1)=0.375ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ´110.375P(A_{1}=1)=0.375 while Pâ€‹(A2=1)=0.8ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ´210.8P(A_{2}=1)=0.8.
Note the client availabilities are assumed to be independent across rounds. Suppose there is a communication constraint which restricts the server to sampling at most a single client each round. The server must thus choose a possibly client state dependent policy for selecting the clients in each round. Each such policy would achieve certain long-term client participation rates across the rounds, denoted ğ«=(r1,r2)ğ«subscriptğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘Ÿ2\mathbf{r}=(r_{1},r_{2}). For example, under the model in TableÂ 1, the set of achievable long-term participation rates across all possible policies is given by the region â„›1subscriptâ„›1\mathcal{R}_{1} shown in FigureÂ 1. Given the communication constraints, it is not possible to achieve the full client participation rates of ğ«=(1,1)ğ«11\mathbf{r}=(1,1) because clients are not always available and we can only sample one client in each round. However, ğ«a=(0.375,0)superscriptğ«ğ‘0.3750\mathbf{r}^{a}=(0.375,0) is achievable by using the state-dependent deterministic policy which selects c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1} whenever c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1} is available and never selects c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2}. Alternatively, ğ«b=(0.375,0.5)superscriptğ«ğ‘0.3750.5\mathbf{r}^{b}=(0.375,0.5) is also achievable by selecting c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1} whenever c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1} is available, and c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2} when only c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2} is available. A naive selection policy that samples from available clients with probability proportional to pi=12subscriptğ‘ğ‘–12p_{i}=\frac{1}{2} in hope of achieving â€œidealâ€ participation rate (12,12)1212(\frac{1}{2},\frac{1}{2}) [22] would actually result in client c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1} participating at a rate of

references: presents average user and sample loss over CIFAR100 and Shakespeare for all availability models. User average first computes the local test metric and then averages over users, while sample metrics computes the metric averaged over all test samples. Typically in deep learning test sample accuracy reflects better performance. However, in federated learning uniform performance across users is desired even if some users have very few datapoints. Below we show that claims in
are also valid for user-averaged metrics. Notice that sample accuracy and user accuracy coincide in CIFAR100 given that data is split in a balanced way among clients so we omit these results.
